text: the United Nations took several steps on
Monday to improve delivery to aid to
people in Haiti Neil mcfarley UN
correspondent for The Times is with me
now and he has the details how would you
describe the feeling inside the UN about
how well it's responded to this crisis
well I mean you know they recognize that
there needs to be a system in place that
is just such a huge task that there it
has to be more organized but I guess
they're sort of pleading for time
because they feel like it's only been
five days logistics are terribly
difficult you know air seal and all that
has been affected by the quake the
system itself the United Nations system
has been affected by but you know all
the NGOs is saying you've got to get it
in place you know we need to have this
working the main problem is the airport
it all has to come to the airport it's
got one runway and you know used to
handle maybe 30 flights a day now it has
to handle over a hundred so they have to
you know send some of them over to the
Dominican Republic so the port sustained
heavy damage in the quake so they're
trying to fix the port because obviously
they could get a lot in that way there
are a couple private airfields around
the country and they're trying to beef
that up now let me ask you about medical
care there's clearly still a shortage of
medical care how is the UN going to help
in that regard they want to move in a
bunch of people are going to try and
move in a tent city of 800 people
because people don't have a place to
work they don't have tensity of un
worker to intensity of 800 for un
workers what about security getting more
police to replace someone who have been
injured or killed in Haiti what's the
plan for that exactly well the Haitian
police have really been sort of badly
set back by this they told UN officials
who were visiting us that they've lost
about half their 4,000 member force in
port-au-prince so they're down to two
thousand so today Ban ki-moon the
secretary-general asked the security
council to send 3,500 more security
officers a combination of police and
soldiers they're nervous about the
potential for the frustration for
boiling over in sort of a global sense
port-au-prince is fairly calm but
there's obviously pockets
where there's trouble and you know
something like distribution of cooking
fuel would suddenly get out of control
so that it's kind of they're doing it
anticipating that there could be
problems as people you know without food
water and shelter gradually get get more
and more angry but at the moment they
don't feel like there's a pressing
security concern I was interested in
something you were saying earlier about
concern on the part of the UN about
sending too many peacekeepers in and the
sort of message that that sends about
who's in control of Haiti talk about
that if you would well there's always
been sort of attention you know the
government there has never run
particularly well in recent years and
there's always been kind of attention
about why you know it needed such a big
United Nations force now they have
helped before all this happened you know
but they're always the Haitian
government very sensitive about its
sovereignty and that you know just like
being rolled over with a bulldozer so
there's some talk of changing the
mandate because now they're sort of in a
more development for a phase and the
rebuilding phase and do they need to
change the the mandate but I i think the
sense of security council's they don't
want to rush into it because you know
they sort of want to get the Haitian
government have chanced it to get back
on his feet and see how that goes
